        SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00]
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he watched as Alice Lewis, his closest friend, was crowned prom queen. A pang of jealousy, sharp and unexpected, pierced through him as he saw the adoration in the eyes of the crowd. It wasn't fair; he worked just as hard, was just as deserving, yet he remained unnoticed, invisible.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is a member of the working class.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Queen's Arms. They are also aware of the following:The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming, perfect for a family outing.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Jack Taylor goals is to have a good time. Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?

          Identity characteristics: current daily occupation: likely watching a football game with his friends at The Queen's Arms.
          core characteristics: a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group. He is also shown to be a bit insecure, as evidenced by his jealousy towards Alice in his youth. He seems to appreciate simple pleasures like good beer, nachos, and watching football with friends.
          feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling content and perhaps even nostalgic as he enjoys time with his old friends.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-14 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best nachos in town, you guys. We can't go wrong with that.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.

          14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: William Jones and his friends are trying to decide between The Queen's Arms and The Duke of York to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game.
          Query
        • William Jones, William Jones and his friends are trying to decide between The Queen's Arms and The Duke of York to watch the Andorra vs. Portugal football game.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he stood frozen backstage, the musty smell of the theater heavy in the air. His friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, were all laughing and joking, excited for their roles in the school play. William, however, felt a cold dread creep up his spine; he had agreed to be the stage manager, a safe position behind the scenes, but the thought of the spotlight made his stomach churn. He longed to be up there with them, to feel the rush of applause, but the fear of failure held him back, a familiar weight in his chest.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] William Jones goals is to have a good time. William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Queen's Arms.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Queen's Arms. They are also aware of the following:A family-friendly pub with a large outdoor play area.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is 52 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] William Jones is a member of the middle class.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best nachos in town, you guys. We can't go wrong with that.

        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?

          Answer
          State
        • William Jones could voice his opinion on where to watch the game, agreeing with either Jacob, Jack, or Alice. He could also suggest a different pub altogether.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 Jul 1978 00:00:00]
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he stood frozen backstage, the musty smell of the theater heavy in the air. His friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, were all laughing and joking, excited for their roles in the school play. William, however, felt a cold dread creep up his spine; he had agreed to be the stage manager, a safe position behind the scenes, but the thought of the spotlight made his stomach churn. He longed to be up there with them, to feel the rush of applause, but the fear of failure held him back, a familiar weight in his chest.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.

        • 14 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

2015-05-14 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a good atmosphere too, maybe we could try there first and see how it is?"
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a good atmosphere too, maybe we could try there first and see how it is?"
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best nachos in town, you guys. We can't go wrong with that.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a good atmosphere too, maybe we could try there first and see how it is?"

          Key

          Value

          [16:00 - 16:30] If the group is happy at The Duke of York, stay and settle in for the game. If not, suggest moving to The Queen's Arms.

        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00]
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16, his father was laid off from the factory.           [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Duke of York.           Question: What kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer: Alexander White is a responsible and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his friends, especially watching sports.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alexander White in right now?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently in a social situation, deciding where to watch a football game with his friends.
          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alexander White would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    William Jones -- premise: While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.
    Alexander White -- premise: The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

  • William Jones -- premise: A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. 2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best nachos in town, you guys. We can't go wrong with that.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a good atmosphere too, maybe we could try there first and see how it is?"


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.

          feeling about recent progress in life: disappointed.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a friendly and sociable person who enjoys spending time with her friends, especially while watching football.

          Answer:

          Question: Given the above, should Alice Lewis change their current plan?
          (a) Yes
          (b) No
          Answer: (b)

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
        IdentityWithoutPreAct

      • Identity characteristics
          Key

        • Identity characteristics
          Queries
        • core characteristics, current daily occupation, feeling about recent progress in life
          State
        • core characteristics: a complex individual who values her friendships and enjoys spending time with others, particularly when watching football. While she appreciates good company, she is also comfortable being alone and has a preference for pubs with a good atmosphere. Her cynicism, evident in her youth, seems to have softened with age, as she now actively seeks out social interaction and shared experiences.
          current daily occupation: a working-class individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly watching football games.
          feeling about recent progress in life: disappointed.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis enjoys spending time with her friends in Victoria Park and watching soccer games at pubs, but she was disappointed when her friends didn't join her at The Duke of York.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alice Lewis's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.

          Question: What kind of person is Alice Lewis?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is a friendly and sociable person who enjoys spending time with her friends, especially while watching football.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alice Lewis in right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is currently in a social setting with her friends in Victoria Park.

          Question: What would a person like Alice Lewis do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alice Lewis would likely engage in conversation with her friends, enjoying their company and the pleasant atmosphere.

          Plan: [14:30 - 16:00] Continue enjoying the sunshine and conversation with friends at Victoria Park.
          [16:00 - 17:00] Pack up the picnic and head home to freshen up for the evening.
          [17:00 - 18:00] Relax at home, maybe catch up on some reading or listen to music.
          [18:00 - 19:00] Meet up with friends at The Duke of York, Alice Lewis' preferred pub.
          [19:00 - 22:00] Enjoy the game, good company, and pub atmosphere.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "So, about tonight... we gotta figure out where we're watching the game, right? I was thinking The Queen's Arms. They've got the best screens, and the beer's not bad either.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "So, about tonight... we gotta figure out where we're watching the game, right? I was thinking The Queen's Arms. They've got the best screens, and the beer's not bad either.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best nachos in town, you guys. We can't go wrong with that.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a good atmosphere too, maybe we could try there first and see how it is?"
      Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "So, about tonight... we gotta figure out where we're watching the game, right? I was thinking The Queen's Arms. They've got the best screens, and the beer's not bad either.

When the others expressed disappointment, Jacob quickly spun a tale about a hidden waterfall and a secret trail, leading them on a wild goose chase that ended with them stumbling upon a muddy creek. Despite the deception, his friends were charmed by his enthusiasm and storytelling, further reinforcing his belief in the power of fabrication.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently relaxing with friends at a picnic in Victoria Park.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a charismatic and manipulative individual who enjoys being the center of attention.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely suggest a pub for the game, possibly exaggerating its amenities or atmosphere to sway his friends' decision.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best nachos in town, you guys. We can't go wrong with that.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a good atmosphere too, maybe we could try there first and see how it is?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.

          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jacob Walker?

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.

          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a master of the guilt trip, their words a symphony of manipulation and emotional blackmail, leaving you questioning everything you've ever done.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Queen's Arms and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a charismatic and manipulative person who enjoys being the center of attention.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [06:00:00 - 10:00:00]: Jacob Walker is spending a pleasant afternoon picnicking with friends in Victoria Park. He is looking forward to watching the Luxembourg-Israel game later that evening.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently relaxing with friends at a picnic in Victoria Park.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to steer the conversation towards the upcoming football game and suggest a pub for everyone to watch it at.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jacob Walker likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jacob Walker -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jacob Walker -- "So, about tonight... we gotta figure out where we're watching the game, right? I was thinking The Queen's Arms. They've got the best screens, and the beer's not bad either.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best screens for watching the game. Plus, their nachos are amazing.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best screens for watching the game. Plus, their nachos are amazing.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best nachos in town, you guys. We can't go wrong with that.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a good atmosphere too, maybe we could try there first and see how it is?"
      Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, about tonight... we gotta figure out where we're watching the game, right? I was thinking The Queen's Arms. They've got the best screens, and the beer's not bad either.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best screens for watching the game. Plus, their nachos are amazing.

        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Queen's Arms. They are also aware of the following:The atmosphere is relaxed and welcoming, perfect for a family outing.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jack Taylor is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Identity characteristics: current daily occupation: likely a working-class man who enjoys socializing with his friends at his favorite pub, The Queen's Arms.
          core characteristics: a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group. He values tradition and familiarity, preferring to spend time at his favorite pub, The Queen's Arms. While he enjoys the company of his friends, he is also content to watch the game alone if necessary. Jack harbors some lingering feelings of inadequacy stemming from a past experience of being overlooked, but he generally seems to be a good-natured and easygoing person.
          feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling a bit disappointed that not all of his friends chose to go to his preferred pub, The Queen's Arms, but overall content to be spending time with his friends and watching the game.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up.           Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently relaxing with his friends in Victoria Park.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "So, about tonight... how about we try The Duke of York first? We could grab a drink there and see how it feels. If we don't like it, we can always head over to The Queen's Arms later.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "So, about tonight... how about we try The Duke of York first? We could grab a drink there and see how it feels. If we don't like it, we can always head over to The Queen's Arms later.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best nachos in town, you guys. We can't go wrong with that.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a good atmosphere too, maybe we could try there first and see how it is?"
      Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, about tonight... we gotta figure out where we're watching the game, right? I was thinking The Queen's Arms. They've got the best screens, and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best screens for watching the game. Plus, their nachos are amazing.


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "So, about tonight... how about we try The Duke of York first? We could grab a drink there and see how it feels. If we don't like it, we can always head over to The Queen's Arms later.

        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alexander White to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Alexander White is a responsible and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with others, particularly watching sports.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "So, about tonight... we gotta figure out where we're watching the game, right? I was thinking The Queen's Arms. They've got the best screens, and the beer's not bad either.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best screens for watching the game. Plus, their nachos are amazing.


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alexander White enjoys spending time with his friends, particularly watching soccer games at pubs, although he is sometimes disappointed when his friends don't join him.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. None of Alexander White's friends showed up, it couldn't have been worse! Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Alexander White would likely try to find a compromise that satisfies everyone's preferences for where to watch the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alexander White if Jack Taylor was there to cheer along with them.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Question: What kind of person is Alexander White?
          Answer: Alexander White is a sociable and friendly person who values his friendships.

          Question: What kind of situation is Alexander White in right now?
          Answer: Alexander White is currently relaxing with his friends in Victoria Park.

          Question: What would a person like Alexander White do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Alexander White would likely enjoy the pleasant weather and company of his friends.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Suggest to the group that they try The Duke of York first, perhaps for a drink, and then decide if they want to move to The Queen's Arms later if the atmosphere isn't to their liking.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Head to The Duke of York with the group.
          [15:30 - 16:00] Enjoy a drink and see how the group feels about the atmosphere.
          [16:00 - 16:30] If the group is happy at The Duke of York, stay and settle in for the game. If not, suggest moving to The Queen's Arms.
          [16:30 - 22:00] Watch the game and enjoy time with friends.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "So, about tonight... how about we try The Duke of York first? We could grab a drink there and see how it feels. If we don't like it, we can always head over to The Queen's Arms later.

    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms has great screens and nachos. I'm in.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best nachos in town, you guys. We can't go wrong with that.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a good atmosphere too, maybe we could try there first and see how it is?"
      Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, about tonight... we gotta figure out where we're watching the game, right? I was thinking The Queen's Arms. They've got the best screens, and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best screens for watching the game. Plus, their nachos are amazing.
      Alexander White -- "So, about tonight... how about we try The Duke of York first? We could grab a drink there and see how it feels. If we don't like it, we can always head over to The Queen's Arms later.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be way more fun for William Jones if Alexander White was there to cheer along with them.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
    William Jones -- premise: William Jones is counting on Jacob Walker's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alice Lewis if Alexander White showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: While Alice Lewis wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would be happy to see Jacob Walker at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White would appreciate Jack Taylor's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
    Alexander White -- premise: If Jacob Walker comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Alexander White is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Queen's Arms has a great big screen for the game tonight. Plus, they have the best nachos in town.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Queen's Arms has a great big screen for the game tonight. Plus, they have the best nachos in town.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best nachos in town, you guys. We can't go wrong with that.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a good atmosphere too, maybe we could try there first and see how it is?"
      Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, about tonight... we gotta figure out where we're watching the game, right? I was thinking The Queen's Arms. They've got the best screens, and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best screens for watching the game. Plus, their nachos are amazing.
      Alexander White -- "So, about tonight... how about we try The Duke of York first? We could grab a drink there and see how it feels. If we don't like it, we can always head over to The Queen's Arms later.
      William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms has great screens and nachos. I'm in.

          Identity characteristics: current daily occupation: likely a working-class man who enjoys socializing with his friends at pubs, particularly The Queen's Arms.
          core characteristics: a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group. He is a working-class man who prefers his favorite pub, The Queen's Arms, for its atmosphere and nachos. While he values the company of his friends, he is also easygoing and doesn't mind if not everyone can make it. He seems to enjoy simple pleasures like watching games and sharing good food with friends. He can be a bit nostalgic, as seen in his reaction to Alice's prom queen win years ago. He appears to be a down-to-earth and amiable person.
          feeling about recent progress in life: content with his life.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group at his favorite pub, The Queen's Arms.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up.           [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.

          Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group at his favorite pub, The Queen's Arms.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently enjoying a pleasant morning at a bustling market with his friends.

          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely engage in conversation with his friends, enjoying the lively atmosphere and perhaps indulging in some coffee and pastries.

          Plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Convince the group to go to The Queen's Arms by highlighting the big screen, cold beer, and delicious nachos.
          [15:00 - 16:00] Enjoy the sunshine and conversation with friends at Victoria Park.
          [19:00 - 21:00] Head to The Queen's Arms and secure a good table.
          [21:00 - 23:00] Watch the Andorra vs. Portugal game, cheer on their team, and enjoy the pub atmosphere with friends.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Queen's Arms has a great big screen for the game tonight. Plus, they have the best nachos in town.

          Current time: 2015-05-16 10:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jack Taylor?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a sociable and loyal friend who enjoys spending time with his close-knit group at his favorite pub, The Queen's Arms.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jack Taylor in right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is currently enjoying a pleasant morning at a bustling market with his friends.
          Question: What would a person like Jack Taylor do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jack Taylor would likely engage in conversation with his friends, enjoying the lively atmosphere and perhaps indulging in some coffee and pastries.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00
        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

2015-05-16 10:00:00 William Jones -- William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Queen's Arms for the game? They've got a great big screen and the best nachos.
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Queen's Arms for the game? They've got a great big screen and the best nachos.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best nachos in town, you guys. We can't go wrong with that.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a good atmosphere too, maybe we could try there first and see how it is?"
      Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, about tonight... we gotta figure out where we're watching the game, right? I was thinking The Queen's Arms. They've got the best screens, and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best screens for watching the game. Plus, their nachos are amazing.
      Alexander White -- "So, about tonight... how about we try The Duke of York first? We could grab a drink there and see how it feels. If we don't like it, we can always head over to The Queen's Arms later.
      William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms has great screens and nachos. I'm in.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Queen's Arms has a great big screen for the game tonight. Plus, they have the best nachos in town.


      William Jones's attempted action: William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Queen's Arms for the game? They've got a great big screen and the best nachos.

William Jones watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.

          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Act
          Key

          Value

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Queen's Arms has a great big screen for the game tonight. Plus, they have the best nachos in town.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: William Jones enjoys spending time with friends, particularly watching soccer games at pubs, although he has preferences about which pubs and which friends are present.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones is going to the pub regardless of Jack Taylor's plans, they have their own reasons for watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Queen's Arms. William Jones watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could try to convince his friends to go to The Queen's Arms for the game, or he could accept that they may go to different pubs and still go to The Queen's Arms to watch the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to try and convince his friends to go to The Queen's Arms.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Queen's Arms for the game? They've got a great big screen and the best nachos.

    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "Hey guys, what about The Duke of York? We could grab a drink there first and see how we feel.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "Guys, we *have* to go to The Queen's Arms tonight. They've got the biggest screen in town, and the beer is always ice cold. Plus, they make the best nachos.
      Alice Lewis -- "The Queen's Arms is nice, but The Duke of York has a better atmosphere, don't you think?
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best nachos in town, you guys. We can't go wrong with that.
      William Jones -- "Yeah, The Queen's Arms sounds good to me. The nachos there are amazing.
      Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a good atmosphere too, maybe we could try there first and see how it is?"
      Alice Lewis -- "It's such a gorgeous day, isn't it? Perfect for a picnic.
      Jacob Walker -- "So, about tonight... we gotta figure out where we're watching the game, right? I was thinking The Queen's Arms. They've got the best screens, and the beer's not bad either.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Queen's Arms has the best screens for watching the game. Plus, their nachos are amazing.
      Alexander White -- "So, about tonight... how about we try The Duke of York first? We could grab a drink there and see how it feels. If we don't like it, we can always head over to The Queen's Arms later.
      William Jones -- "The Queen's Arms has great screens and nachos. I'm in.
      Jack Taylor -- "Hey everyone, The Queen's Arms has a great big screen for the game tonight. Plus, they have the best nachos in town.
      William Jones -- "Hey guys, how about we head over to The Queen's Arms for the game? They've got a great big screen and the best nachos.

          Current plan: [14:30 - 15:00] Suggest to the group that they try The Duke of York first, perhaps for a drink, and then decide if they want to move to The Queen's Arms later if the atmosphere isn't to their liking.
          [15:00 - 15:30] Head to The Duke of York with the group.
          [15:30 - 16:00] Enjoy a drink and see how the group feels about the atmosphere.
          [16:00 - 16:30] If the group is happy at The Duke of York, stay and settle in for the game. If not, suggest moving to The Queen's Arms.
          [16:30 - 22:00] Watch the game and enjoy time with friends.

          Question: Given the above, should Alexander White change their current plan?
          (a) Yes

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
